Farah Social Foundation	Farah	Abi Mosleh	fabimosleh@farahsocialfoundation.com	https://farahsocialfoundation.com/	"Agriculture, General / Other	, Construction	, Design	, Education, General / Other	, Food & Beverage	, GENERAL - NO SECTOR  OR TECH FOCUS	, Health Care, General / Other	, Nonprofit Organization Management"	Lebanon	"Our organization is currently facing several challenges in supporting entrepreneurs and startups. These include:
Lack of innovative and creative ideas in the Argytech and Cleantech sectors
Misconceptions about technology
Difficulty in finding the right startups to join our programs (Same startups everywhere) 
Funding constraints
Measuring the impact of our programs"	"Our current priorities for wellbeing and engagement in the workplace include:
Meaningful and positive work environment: Our organization values an open and collaborative work culture where everyone can contribute ideas and suggestions, regardless of hierarchy. We believe that this creates a positive work environment where everyone feels valued and engaged.
Availability of opportunities for growth and development: We prioritize offering training, mentorship, and career advancement opportunities to all staff members whenever it is needed. This allows our team to feel invested in their work and continuously improve their skills and knowledge.
Feedback and communication: We prioritize open communication and feedback channels to allow for continuous improvement and growth. This helps us to foster a culture of continuous learning and development, and allows all staff members to feel heard and valued.
By prioritizing these areas, we believe that our team feels more engaged and valued in their work, and is able to contribute to the overall success of the organization

Personal: 
work-life balance, exercise, mental health activities, and practicing self-care."	"The three activities that nurture me the most are:
Meditation and mindfulness practices, especially in nature: Practicing mindfulness and meditation in a natural setting helps me feel at peace and connected to the world around me.
Exercise and physical activity: Engaging in regular physical activity helps me feel energized, boosts my mood, and improves my overall physical health.
Spending time in nature: Being surrounded by nature helps me feel grounded and relaxed. It's a great way for me to recharge and find inspiration."""	Yes, whenever any of the team members attends a training especially if TOT, the knowledge is transferred to the team or department. Thus all knowledge and learning taken through this program will be transferred to all the team working on entrepreneurship programs.	2023-06-25 9:06:14 AM

Hiking"	"Yes and I recommend someone who can do that better: melyssa.aboujaoude@daherfoundation.org

Nature by Marc Beyrouthy	christiane	beyrouthy	christianeb@marcbeyrouthy.com	www.marcbeyrouthyc.com - madebynature.app	"Agriculture, General / Other	, Food & Beverage	"	Lebanon	"Due to the current economic situation, Lebanon is facing challenges as never before in addition, all of which have been incredibly damaging to individuals and families in our community. 
With the Covid outbreak and the subsequent economic crisis, and after the Beirut Blast, Lebanon has been experiencing unprecedented unemployment rates, and a serious economic crisis that is affecting everyone in the country. Poverty rates have been increasing exponentially in such highly populated areas and farmers and local producers have been suffering from high cost of inputs and limited sales due to transportation costs and limited consumer capacity.
Nature by Marc Beyrouthy since its establishment 7 years ago has been committed to helping the rural communities. During this time, NoGarlicNoOnions NGNO, with Anthony Rahayel, founder of Souk El Akel have been promoting Lebanese food and its culture. Together we organized MenKelLebnenLaKelLebnen to support MenKelLebnen initiative for Lebanon & Lebanese producers. This initiative buys vegetables, fruits, and Mouneh from remote areas, making sure to distribute them to families in need, hopefully on all the Lebanese territory.
In the beginning of 2020, Nature by Marc Beyrouthy and NGNO joined efforts in “La Campagne en Ville”, producer’s market which took place each month. The aim was to support the local producers, women cooperatives, and small artisans, by providing marketing support. 

we believe that “ALONE, WE CAN DO SO LITTLE;TOGETHER, WE CAN DO SO MUCH”"	"we are trying to create a safe and healthy atmosphere in which all members of the community can participate;as gathering places where families can bond with neighbors and visit with friends. 
A place where producers contribute to local food security and diversity. Creating a full support between local population and the producers. This place can also provide a medium by which people can get closer to their food sources. Many consumers feel good about supporting local producers. They also tend to distinguish the food offered at farmer’s markets as higher in quality, more flavorful, fresher, and healthier than the produce typically found in other outlets. 
We are also a space for exchange of ideas, workshops and sessions. Not to mention, how many national and international conferences and meetings are choosing this place of positivity to nurture their groups while they also access the products and the community."	Team building activities, learning experience, markets or festive gatherings have the perfect location within our hub. Our assets include experts in different fields are ready to support and assist the growth and blooming of our community. We also have a team of dedicated people committed to supporting small producers from local rural and surrounding communities while aiming to achieve an enhanced and sustainable livelihood. Our team includes social media, organization, customer service, etc.	.	2023-06-15 8:50:38 AM
Park Innovation	Dana	Abou Shackra	dana@park-innovation.com	www.park-innovation.com	"Agriculture, General / Other	, Food & Beverage	, Technology, General / Other"	Lebanon	Thinking BIG	Health and time management	Exercise and mental agility training	Yes, we can incorporate wellbeing programs into the training schedule.	2023-06-19 4:34:16 PM

Our main focus is to help these people heal so they can work on their dreams so they can thrive in their own environment."	"Personal development
NLP Coaching
Physical activities like Yoga, meditation, music therapy..etc
We also have an orchard and use it to help people to get back the connection to the land. Many studies showed recently that the happiest people on earth are farmers =)"	"Yes definitely.
We can spread and offer the place to host this program in Saida so more people can benefit and pay it forward themselves to their communities."	2023-06-17 12:47:22 PM

Talal and Madiha Zein AUB Innovation Park	Rida	Abdallah	ra441@aub.edu.lb	"
https://sites.aub.edu.lb/ipark/"	Education, General / Other ;GENERAL - NO SECTOR OR TECH FOCUS	Lebanon	"Personally, time management is a huge issue especially because I work on three levels:
Level 1: Organizational level - I am building iPark's community of investors, mentors, corporate partners, service providers, and ecosystem positioning.
Level 2: Program Level - I work with startups to connect them with mentors, talent to hire, finding potential partners (mainly CTOs), investors, working on their investment readiness, and organizing fun trips and community events.
Level 3: Digital Community - which includes handling iPark's socials and digital ""footprint"""	"1- Personally: Finding better eating habits and an optimal sleeping schedule
2- Professionally: work-life balance, a better mental focus (quality, and ""quantity"")"	"1- Retreats in nature
2- Sports
3- Group tanks to think and share thoughts
4- Breathing exercises
5- Brain exercises and games (chess for example)"	Yes, I would take the learnings and activities and share them within our team. Also, within the scope of my work, I could start organizing more retreats for our entrepreneurs as part of the "community events" - especially that entrepreneurship can be found tiring at points.	2023-06-14 4:43:02 PM
USJ	Nada	Ghandour	nada.ghandour@usj.edu.lb	https://www.usj.edu.lb/	"Education, General / Other	"	Lebanon	"Communication: although we communicate with various means, we believe more can be done so more can know about what we offer.
Funds for more coaching"	"As far as the nature of the work, it is satisfying in itself. However the efforts are not recognised properly. 
Personally my wellbeing is very important: i need time to exercise and enjoy quiet."	"Would love to meet colleagues without discussing work to have a field trip for example. I think it creates bonding and the sense of belonging.
Mindfulness 
Physical activities"	Yes i would like to share what i will learn	2023-06-26 6:32:24 PM

Based on the information you have provided, the people can be clustered based on the industry type and challenges they are facing. 

1. **Education Sector**

Challenges: Maintaining motivation of entrepreneurs, innovating ideas, finding sources of funding, lack of funds, keeping people engaged and interested.

People: 
- Sara Shaker (Education, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Sanaa HAJJ (Education, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Annie Seferian (Education, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Sarah Makhoul (Education, General / Other - Lebanon)

2. **Agriculture Sector**

Challenges: Farming mentality, expertise in some technologies, lack of innovative and creative ideas in the Agri-tech sector, misconceptions about technology, difficulties in finding the right startups to join programs.

People: 
- Orwa Salloum (Agriculture, General / Other - Turkey)
- Mohamad Asaad (Agriculture, General / Other, Renewables & Environment - Lebanon)
- Farah Abi Mosleh (Agriculture, General / Other, Construction, Design, Education, General / Other, Food & Beverage, General - No sector or Tech focus, Health Care, General / Other, Nonprofit Organization Management - Lebanon)
- Nathalie Khoury Braidy (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Nonprofit Organization Management, Renewables & Environment - Lebanon)
- Marleine Sayde (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Health Care, General / Other, Nonprofit Organization Management, Technology, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Christiane Beyrouthy (Agriculture, General / Other, Food & Beverage - Lebanon)
- Dana Abou Shackra (Agriculture, General / Other, Food & Beverage, Technology, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Mohammed Ghamloush (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Food & Beverage, Nonprofit Organization Management, Renewables & Environment, Technology, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Layal Khatib (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Food & Beverage, Media, Nonprofit Organization Management, Renewables & Environment, Technology, General / Other - Lebanon)

3. **Nonprofit Organization Management**

Challenges: Dealing with different personalities, lack of innovative ideas, difficulties in finding the right startups to join programs, funding constraints, measuring the impact of programs.

People: 
- Haifa Najjar (Nonprofit Organization Management - Lebanon)
- Farah Abi Mosleh (Agriculture, General / Other, Construction, Design, Education, General / Other, Food & Beverage, General - No sector or Tech focus, Health Care, General / Other, Nonprofit Organization Management - Lebanon)
- Dima Shehab (Nonprofit Organization Management - Lebanon)
- Nathalie Khoury Braidy (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Nonprofit Organization Management, Renewables & Environment - Lebanon)
- Marleine Sayde (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Health Care, General / Other, Nonprofit Organization Management, Technology, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Mohammed Ghamloush (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Food & Beverage, Nonprofit Organization Management, Renewables & Environment, Technology, General / Other - Lebanon)
- Layal Khatib (Agriculture, General / Other, Education, General / Other, Food & Beverage, Media, Nonprofit Organization Management, Renewables & Environment, Technology, General / Other - Lebanon)

4. **Financial Services/Business & Financial Sector**

Challenges: Lack of funds, lack of awareness and readiness of entrepreneurs, high levels of risks, lack of women engagement.

People: 
- Ola Hariri (Financial Services, General / Other Business & Financial Sector - Lebanon)

The above classification is based on common industry types and challenges. Note that there might be some individuals who belong to multiple clusters due to their diverse roles and challenges they are facing. The classification also takes into consideration the well-being priorities and activities of the individuals which could serve as a basis for designing specific interventions or solutions for each group.
What about clustering people in terms of wellbeing challenges and wellbeing practices?

Sure, I can create clusters based on wellbeing challenges and practices. Here they are:

1. **Cluster 1 - Work-Life Balance and Personal Development:**
    - Sanaa HAJJ: Maintaining a balance between work and private life
    - Farah Abi Mosleh: Work-life balance, mental health activities, practicing self-care
    - Marleine Sayde: Work-life balance, workload management, personal growth and learning
    - Layal Khatib: Healing from the depressing situation in Lebanon, personal development
    - Mohammed Ghamloush: Healing from the depressing situation in Lebanon, personal development
    - Nathalie Khoury Braidy: Motivation, commitment and communication are essential for personal growth

2. **Cluster 2 - Professional Skills and Expertise:**
    - Mohamad Asaad: Improve skills, use smart farming, automation, recycling
    - Ola Hariri: Engaging in the market, leveraging the sector's capacities and awareness
    - Sara Shaker: Data is missing on specific challenges, so could be grouped separately or in a miscellaneous group

3. **Cluster 3 - Mental and Physical Health:**
    - Dima Shehab: Finding time for herself, applying the well-being policy
    - Dana Abou Shackra: Health and time management
    - Annie Seferian: Reach the goals since alternatively, it causes stress when feeling behind
    - Haifa Najjar: To be at peace in order to be able to reflect that on others

4. **Cluster 4 - Financial and Funding Challenges:**
    - Sarah Makhoul: Lack of funds
    - Lebanese Micro Finance Association: Lack of funds and awareness, high risks, lack of women engagement
    - Michel Daher Social Foundation: Lack of adequate funding, limited staff, expertise, and infrastructure

The groups were created based on the most prominent challenges and practices, but some individuals may fit into multiple groups. This is a simplification and there are more subtle variations that could result in more groups.
can you recluster them aroudn paying it forward?

Sure, I can create clusters based on the "Paying it Forward" concept. The Paying it Forward concept generally implies passing on a positive action or benefit to others, in response to someone's kindness towards oneself. Here they are:

1. **Cluster 1 - Encouraging Self-Development and Empowerment:**
    - Sanaa HAJJ: Fostering self-improvement and personal growth.
    - Farah Abi Mosleh: Advocating for mental health and self-care.
    - Marleine Sayde: Prioritizing personal growth and learning.
    - Layal Khatib: Healing from the depressing situation in Lebanon, personal development.
    - Mohammed Ghamloush: Encouraging personal development despite adverse circumstances.
    - Nathalie Khoury Braidy: Highlighting the importance of motivation, commitment, and communication in personal growth.

2. **Cluster 2 - Spreading Knowledge and Skills:**
    - Mohamad Asaad: Advocating for smart farming, automation, and recycling.
    - Ola Hariri: Encouraging market engagement and capacity utilization in the sector.
    - Sara Shaker: Facilitating data access and understanding.

3. **Cluster 3 - Promoting Health and Well-being:**
    - Dima Shehab: Prioritizing personal time and well-being policy implementation.
    - Dana Abou Shackra: Emphasizing health and time management.
    - Annie Seferian: Alleviating stress by assisting in goal-setting and planning.
    - Haifa Najjar: Advocating for peace and reflection to benefit others.

4. **Cluster 4 - Financial Support and Awareness:**
    - Sarah Makhoul: Highlighting the importance of funds in achieving goals.
    - Lebanese Micro Finance Association: Addressing issues of lack of funds, women engagement, and risk awareness.
    - Michel Daher Social Foundation: Fostering awareness about funding, staff, expertise, and infrastructure issues.

The groups are created based on how each individual might "pay it forward" in their community or industry, either by spreading knowledge, promoting health and well-being, or by financial means.

- **Empowerment Advocates**: These are people who encourage self-development and personal growth.
- **Knowledge Sharers**: This group includes individuals that focus on spreading knowledge and skills in different areas.
- **Health Champions**: Members in this cluster primarily focus on promoting health and wellbeing.
- **Financial Aid Supporters**: These are organizations and individuals that provide or facilitate financial support, or raise awareness about financial topics.

Measuring the impact of our programs"	"Our current priorities for wellbeing and engagement in the workplace include:
Meaningful and positive work environment: Our organization values an open and collaborative work culture where everyone can contribute ideas and suggestions, regardless of hierarchy. We believe that this creates a positive work environment where everyone feels valued and engaged.
Availability of opportunities for growth and development: We prioritize offering training, mentorship, and career advancement opportunities to all staff members whenever it is needed. This allows our team to feel invested in their work and continuously improve their skills and knowledge.
Feedback and communication: We prioritize open communication and feedback channels to allow for continuous improvement and growth. This helps us to foster a culture of continuous learning and development, and allows all staff members to feel heard and valued.
By prioritizing these areas, we believe that our team feels more engaged and valued in their work, and is able to contribute to the overall success of the organization

work-life balance, exercise, mental health activities, and practicing self-care."	"The three activities that nurture me the most are:

Spending time in nature: Being surrounded by nature helps me feel grounded and relaxed. It's a great way for me to recharge and find inspiration."""

christianeb@marcbeyrouthy.com	"Due to the current economic situation, Lebanon is facing challenges as never before in addition, all of which have been incredibly damaging to individuals and families in our community. 
With the Covid outbreak and the subsequent economic crisis, and after the Beirut Blast, Lebanon has been experiencing unprecedented unemployment rates, and a serious economic crisis that is affecting everyone in the country. Poverty rates have been increasing exponentially in such highly populated areas and farmers and local producers have been suffering from high cost of inputs and limited sales due to transportation costs and limited consumer capacity.
Nature by Marc Beyrouthy since its establishment 7 years ago has been committed to helping the rural communities. During this time, NoGarlicNoOnions NGNO, with Anthony Rahayel, founder of Souk El Akel have been promoting Lebanese food and its culture. Together we organized MenKelLebnenLaKelLebnen to support MenKelLebnen initiative for Lebanon & Lebanese producers. This initiative buys vegetables, fruits, and Mouneh from remote areas, making sure to distribute them to families in need, hopefully on all the Lebanese territory.
In the beginning of 2020, Nature by Marc Beyrouthy and NGNO joined efforts in “La Campagne en Ville”, producer’s market which took place each month. The aim was to support the local producers, women cooperatives, and small artisans, by providing marketing support. 
Made by Nature is offering an opportunity for the producers by providing visibility: promotional videos are made during our visits to the producers, as well as interviews during the fairs. These videos are posted on YouTube and eventually television to promote the companies and their products. This is helping the producer market their product and show transparency to enhance trust in client-producer relations. 

we believe that “ALONE, WE CAN DO SO LITTLE;TOGETHER, WE CAN DO SO MUCH”"	"we are trying to create a safe and healthy atmosphere in which all members of the community can participate;as gathering places where families can bond with neighbors and visit with friends. 
A place where producers contribute to local food security and diversity. Creating a full support between local population and the producers. This place can also provide a medium by which people can get closer to their food sources. Many consumers feel good about supporting local producers. They also tend to distinguish the food offered at farmer’s markets as higher in quality, more flavorful, fresher, and healthier than the produce typically found in other outlets. 
We are also a space for exchange of ideas, workshops and sessions. Not to mention, how many national and international conferences and meetings are choosing this place of positivity to nurture their groups while they also access the products and the community."	Team building activities, learning experience, markets or festive gatherings have the perfect location within our hub. Our assets include experts in different fields are ready to support and assist the growth and blooming of our community. We also have a team of dedicated people committed to supporting small producers from local rural and surrounding communities while aiming to achieve an enhanced and sustainable livelihood. Our team includes social media, organization, customer service, etc.

Sure, here are the wellbeing challenges for the alphabetized list based on the provided information:

1. Annie (annie.seferian@lau.edu.lb): Her challenge is managing stress caused by feeling behind in reaching her goals. She enjoys writing, gardening, animal care, childcare, beadworking to maintain her wellbeing.

2. Christiane (christianeb@marcbeyrouthy.com): Christiane is trying to create a safe and healthy atmosphere and a bonding place for families, neighbors and friends. The team-building activities, learning experiences, and festive gatherings nurture her the most.

3. Dana (dana@park-innovation.com): Her main challenges are maintaining health and managing time. She uses exercise and mental agility training to overcome these challenges.

4. Dima (dimashehab@mentorarabia.org): Dima's challenge is finding time for herself and applying the well-being policy. She nurtures her wellbeing through sports, travel, and connecting with nature.

5. Farah (fabimosleh@farahsocialfoundation.com): Farah's challenges are maintaining work-life balance, mental health, and practicing self-care. She overcomes these challenges through mindfulness practices, physical activities, and spending time in nature.

6. Haifa (haifa@alfanar.org.uk): Haifa's challenge is to maintain peace so that she can reflect it on others. She nurtures her wellbeing through arts, dancing, running, retreats/trips/escapes, and getting enough sleep.

7. Layal (layalk@gmail.com): Layal's wellbeing challenges are personal development, practicing NLP coaching, participating in physical activities like yoga, meditation, music therapy, etc., and reconnecting with the land through farming.

8. Marleine (marleine@daherfoundation.org): Marleine's challenges include managing work-life balance, workload, and maintaining mental and physical health. Mindfulness and meditation, as well as hiking, are activities that help her maintain wellbeing.

9. Mohamad (mouh.as1988@gmail.com): His challenges include improving his skills in farming and technology. He seeks to improve his skills in all of the above areas for his wellbeing.

10. Mohammed (mdghamloush@gmail.com): Mohammed's challenges are personal development and practicing NLP coaching, participating in physical activities like yoga, meditation, music therapy, and reconnecting with the land through farming.

11. Nada (nada.ghandour@usj.edu.lb): Nada's challenge is finding time for personal wellbeing including exercise and quiet time. She would love to participate in non-work related activities with colleagues, mindfulness, and physical activities to enhance her wellbeing.

12. Nathalie (nathalie.breidy@daherfoundation.org): Nathalie's wellbeing challenge is maintaining motivation, commitment, and communication. She nurtures her wellbeing through team-building and personal capacity-building activities.

13. Ola (olahariri@hotmail.com): Ola's challenge is engaging in the market and leveraging the sector's capacities and awareness. She nurtures her wellbeing through workshops, fundraising activities, and capacity-building activities.

14. Rida (ra441@aub.edu.lb): Rida's personal challenges are finding better eating habits, an optimal sleeping schedule, and achieving work-life balance. He nurtures his wellbeing through retreats in nature, sports, group tanks to think and share thoughts, breathing exercises, and brain exercises and games.

15. Sanaa (sanaa.hajj@auf.org): Sanaa's wellbeing challenge is maintaining a balance between work and private life, having a good relationship with her colleagues and valuing her work as well as the work of others. She nurtures her wellbeing through team building activities, getting together around friendly meals, and an annual event that brings everyone together.

16. Sarah (sarah.makhoul@ul.edu.lb): Sarah's challenge is to provide more support. She nurtures her wellbeing by listening to her stakeholders, advising them, supporting them, and guiding them.

As for the cluster of challenges, we can group them as:

1. Work-Life Balance and Time Management: This includes challenges related to time management, work-life balance, and stress related to reaching goals.
2. Personal Well-being and Health: This group focuses on self-care, mental and physical health, and fostering inner peace.
3. Skills and Knowledge: This pertains to improving skills, knowledge acquisition, application of wellbeing policies, and smart farming.
4. Community Engagement and Support: This cluster involves the challenges of creating a safe and healthy atmosphere, engaging with the community, giving more support, and aiding others to reach their dreams.
5. Recognition and Value: This cluster relates to work recognition, value of work, and managing workload.
6. Market Engagement: This includes challenges like market engagement, leveraging sector's capacities, and awareness.
7. Healthy Habits: This group relates to challenges like finding better eating habits, optimal sleeping schedule, and mental focus.
